DOCNAME: CASE OF GORGIEV v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
CONCLUSION: Preliminary objection joined to merits and dismissed (Article 35-1 - Exhaustion of domestic remedies);Violation of Article 3 - Prohibition of torture (Article 3 - Effective investigation) (Procedural aspect);No violation of Article 3 - Prohibition of torture (Article 3 - Positive obligations) (Substantive aspect);Non-pecuniary damage - award
JUDGES: Ganna Yudkivska;Isabelle Berro-Lefèvre;Julia Laffranque;Karel Jungwiert;Mark Villiger;Mirjana Lazarova Trajkovska;Peer Lorenzen
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in PERSON .

CARDINAL . By a court decision of CARDINAL DATE , the applicant was sentenced to CARDINAL months’ imprisonment for causing serious injury ( a broken forearm ) to a third person . On DATE he started serving his sentence in FAC ( “ the prison ” ) where he was responsible for livestock .

CARDINAL . On DATE he was attacked by a bull , which was not castrated , as a result of which he sustained numerous bodily injuries . After the incident he was transferred by prison vehicle to Štip hospital , where he underwent surgery . The ORG covered the medical expenses . On DATE the bull was put down . On CARDINAL DATE the applicant was released from the hospital . DATE , Mr GPE , the prison governor , ordered him to be released early from prison on account of good behaviour .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant brought a civil action against the ORG and the prison ( “ the defendants ” ) claiming non - pecuniary damages for the injuries sustained by the bull . His claim was based , inter alia , on sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the then valid LAW ( see paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL below ) . He claimed that the bull had attacked him despite the fact that the prison authorities had been alerted about the aggressiveness of the bull , by himself and a certain PERSON ( the first name of Mr PERSON , as established in the course of the compensation proceedings , later referred to as Mr PERSON ) .

CARDINAL . At a hearing of DATE , Mr PERSON stated that he , with the applicant and Mr GPE , had been looking after CARDINAL animals , including the bull . He confirmed that the bull had attacked him and other prisoners , including Mr GPE and Mr GPE , and that PERSON , a prison guard on duty , had been warned on several occasions before the incident about the aggressiveness of the bull . In a certified written statement of DATE , Mr GPE , a prisoner at that time , confirmed that the bull had been aggressive and that Mr A.B. had been informed of the fact .

CARDINAL . Mr A.B. stated that the applicant , in view of his previous experience in handling cattle , had asked to work on the prison farm . Due to his good behaviour , the prison authorities had granted his request despite initial concerns related to his criminal record . After a DATE ’s work - related induction course , the applicant started working on the prison farm . He remained on the farm for DATE before he was allowed pasture duties . That corresponded to the practice already established in the prison . After the incident the bull was lame , which according to him , had been due to the injuries on his buttocks . He had called PERSON , a vet , to examine the bull . DATE , in the presence of PERSON , the bull had been put down . He denied that the applicant or any other prisoner had ever alerted him that the bull was aggressive .

CARDINAL . Mr PERSON , a prisoner at that time who worked on the prison farm , stated that before the incident prisoners had often provoked the bull . He had not heard that any prisoner had ever mentioned , to the prison authorities or to him , that the bull was aggressive .

CARDINAL . At a hearing of DATE , PERSON stated that the bull had been regularly examined and treated when needed . He denied that it had been aggressive . He confirmed that immediately after the incident he had visually examined the bull and noticed injuries to the rear of its body , the buttocks and testicles , which according to him , had been inflicted by a blunt object . Those injuries were confirmed in the post mortem report which PERSON had drawn up DATE .

CARDINAL . The applicant objected to this report , arguing , inter alia , that ( CARDINAL ) it was inaccurate , ( CARDINAL ) it was biased and had been ordered by the ORG , as was evident from the date , DATE , which had been stamped on it and ( CARDINAL ) it could not have been post mortem , since on DATE , DATE it had allegedly been drawn up , the bull was still alive .

CARDINAL . At a hearing on DATE the applicant stated that owing to his DATE experience in rearing livestock he had been assigned to work on the prison farm . Initially , the bull was not aggressive , but it had become anxious during the cows’ mating season . He confirmed Mr PERSON ’s statement ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) and denied that he had ever hit the bull . He maintained that he had alerted PERSON about the aggressiveness of the bull , but that he had never informed , orally or in writing , Mr GPE , the prison governor .

CARDINAL . On DATE the first - instance court ruled partly in favour of the applicant , ordering the ORG to pay him compensation in the amount of MONEY ( ORG , equivalent to MONEY ( ORG ) ) for the injuries , which an expert established as serious . The court established that the ORG owned the bull , which was considered dangerous within the meaning of section CARDINAL of LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . Referring to the above statements , the court established that the bull had been aggressive and had attacked others . It further rejected as unsubstantiated the arguments of the ORG that the applicant had contributed to the incident by hitting the bull . In this connection it disregarded the expert report of PERSON for the reasons advanced in the applicant ’s objection ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .
CARDINAL . Both parties appealed .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG remitted the case for fresh consideration so that the lower court could establish who had owned the bull .

CARDINAL . In this respect , the defendants submitted in evidence extracts from the court register according to which an economic unit PERSON ( “ the economic unit ” ) , which operated as a separate legal entity within the prison , had been the owner of the bull . The economic unit was established on DATE by a decision of the Government . It was run by Mr M.K.

CARDINAL . In a submission of DATE , the applicant argued that the defendants had been responsible for the injuries , in particular due to the fact that they had failed , despite having been alerted about the aggressiveness of the bull , to take any measures to protect him .

CARDINAL . At a hearing of DATE , Mr PERSON stated that no prisoner had ever complained about the aggressiveness of the bull , either to Mr PERSON or to him . He confirmed that the economic unit was the owner of the bull , that it was a separate legal entity and that he ran it , as provided for in section CARDINAL of LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . He further submitted that the applicant had received a DATE work - related allowance from the economic unit .

CARDINAL . NORP The applicant reiterated that he had complained orally to PERSON about the aggressiveness of the bull on several occasions , but that no complaint whatsoever had been submitted to Mr PERSON

CARDINAL . On DATE the first - instance court dismissed the applicant ’s claim , as the defendants did not have the necessary capacity to act in the proceedings . Relying on the extract from the court register ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) and Mr PERSON ’s statement , it found that the economic unit was the owner of the bull , and that accordingly the defendants bore no responsibility , under section CARDINAL of LAW , for the injuries the applicant had sustained . In support was an invoice dated after the killing of the bull , according to which the prison had paid the economic unit for the meat . The applicant was ordered to pay the defendants’ costs .

CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE the applicant appealed , arguing that no consideration had been given to the ORG ’s responsibility for ORG health and physical integrity , given that he had been injured while in custody . He argued that ORG rights and freedoms should be guaranteed by putting in place control and supervisory mechanisms . He further complained that the first - instance court had failed to establish whether the ORG , being responsible to protect him while in custody , had undertaken all necessary measures to avoid damage from occurring . In this latter respect , he complained that the prison authorities , despite having been informed that the bull was aggressive , had failed to take any measure to protect him ( the applicant ) . Lastly , he argued that he had been ordered to look after livestock by the prison authorities .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s appeal , finding no grounds to depart from the established facts and reasoning given by the lower court . The applicant received this decision on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant requested the public prosecutor to lodge a request for the protection of legality with ORG . On DATE the public prosecutor informed him that there were no grounds for using that remedy .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of LAW , as relevant at that time , provided that damage related to a dangerous item was presumed to have been caused by that item , if not otherwise proven .
CARDINAL . Under section CARDINAL , the owner of a dangerous item was responsible for any damage caused by it .

CARDINAL . Under section CARDINAL , a compensation claim became time - barred DATE after the victim became aware of the damage and the person responsible . The absolute time - bar for compensation was DATE after the occurrence of the damage .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of LAW , as relevant at that time , provided for respect for the human dignity and the physical and moral integrity of persons serving a sentence .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) provided that no one should be subjected to torture or to inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment . The right to security of person had to be ensured .
CARDINAL . Under LAW ( CARDINAL ) , convicted persons could not be required to perform activities that were dangerous and detrimental to their health .
CARDINAL . Under LAW , CARDINAL or more economic units for prisoners to work in could be organised within a prison .
CARDINAL . Section DATE provided that the Government should set up the economic units .
CARDINAL . Under section DATE , the prison governor or a person authorised by the governor was to run the economic unit .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL provided that the economic unit was a separate legal entity liable for its debts . It was to have a separate account .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL provided that prisoners worked , in principle , in economic units .
CARDINAL . Under LAW , prisoners were entitled to a work - related allowance . This was to be regulated by a decision of the prison governor .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL provided that prisoners could lodge an oral complaint with the prison governor or other person authorised by the governor about a violation of their rights or other irregularities .
CARDINAL . Under section CARDINAL , prisoners could also lodge a written complaint with the prison governor within DATE of the alleged violation .

CARDINAL . NORP Under section CARDINAL , the prison governor was required to consider the allegations and to render a decision within DATE of receipt of the complaint . The prisoner could appeal against that decision before ORG ( “ the Directorate ” ) .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL provided that the ORG was required to examine the arguments of the appeal and reach a decision within DATE of receipt . That decision could be subject of judicial review . The prisoner could seek a judicial decision even if the ORG had not decided on his or her appeal .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the Criminal Code prohibits torture and provides for imprisonment DATE .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the Criminal Code provides that a person who , in the performance of his duties , mistreats , intimidates , insults or generally treats another in such a manner that his human dignity or personality is humiliated is to be punished by a term of imprisonment of DATE .

CARDINAL . Under section CARDINAL of LAW , a person who failed , in the absence of any risk , to report to a competent authority or to take any measure against a fire , inundation , explosion or car accident or to remove any danger to the life or body of an individual would be fined or sentenced to a maximum of DATE imprisonment .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of LAW provides that criminal proceedings must be instituted at the request of an authorised prosecutor . In cases involving offences subject to prosecution by the State of its own motion or on an application by the injured party , the authorised prosecutor is the public prosecutor , whereas in cases involving offences for which only private charges may be brought the authorised prosecutor is the private prosecutor . If the public prosecutor finds no grounds for the institution or continuation of criminal proceedings , his role may be assumed by the injured party , acting as a subsidiary prosecutor under the conditions specified in the LAW .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL provides , inter alia , that where the public prosecutor finds that there are no grounds for prosecuting an offence which may be subject to ORG prosecution , he shall notify the injured party of his decision within DATE . He shall also inform the injured party that he is entitled to conduct the prosecution himself . The latter may take over or continue the prosecution within DATE .
CARDINAL . Under LAW , anyone can report a criminal offence subject to ORG prosecution . The complaint is submitted to the public prosecutor , orally or in writing .
